utterances: NPR's Eric Westervelt in Jerusalem.
Thanks very much.
You're welcome.
At the United Nations today a straw vote will be held to identify key contenders in the race to succeed Kofi Annan.
The real vote for the new secretary-general will take place in December.
Today's straw poll is intended to weed out the weak candidates and encourage the stronger ones.
For more, we go now to Mark Turner, the United Nations correspondent for the Financial Times.
He joins us from his office at the United Nations.
Welcome, Mark.
Hi, hello.
So who are the frontrunners?
Well, the frontrunner is pretty clear.
I don't even know if there are frontrunners.
At this stage there's one man who appears to be in a pretty commanding lead: Ban Ki Moon, the foreign minister of South Korea.
Last straw poll he got 14 encouragements from the 15 members of the Security Council and one against.
That's what they're called, encouragements?
That is so gentile.
Well, (unintelligible) diplomatically here.
You don't vote a yes or a no. You encourage or discourage.
It's seen as a little bit more polite, I guess.
It also allows you to change your opinion and also to encourage more than one candidate.
In this hour, we'll look back at what happened yesterday and who won, who lost, and why.
And we want to hear from those of you who participated.
If you voted, caucused, or worked the election, call us.
Describe what it looked and felt like, and what other voters were saying and doing.
We have two phone lines for you today, one for Republicans and one for Democrats.
If you're an independent, you can call either line.
The Republican line: 800-344-3893.
Again, that's 800-344-3893 for Republicans and independents.
The number for Democrats and independents: 800-344-3864.
And everybody can send us e-mail, that address is talk@npr.org.
With us on little sleep but lots of energy is Ken Rudin, NPR's political editor.
His Political Junkie column appears weekly on NPR's Web site.
Ken, nice to have you with us today.
Ah, as a matter of speaking, I think I am with you today, yes.
And let's begin with unfinished business from last night which includes the Democratic primaries in Missouri and in New Mexico.
Well, both are obviously very close.
Barack Obama has a lead in both.
We're perhaps may be pretty close to calling Missouri for Barack Obama.
We had called it earlier for Hillary Clinton, but there was an Obama surge late last night, then it went too close to call, and we went to sleep not knowing who would win.
Many networks had already Missouri for Obama.
It looks like Obama may win the state of Missouri, which would be a big pickup for him.
New Mexico - very, very close.
The last I saw with a couple of hundred votes was an Obama lead, too close to call.
But also interesting because Andy Kohut who's here will talk about the demographics and everything and how the Latino vote in California was overwhelmingly for Hillary Clinton over Barack Obama.
But in heavily Hispanic New Mexico, almost a dead even state at this point.
So it's going to be a complicated analysis.
Again, we'll be talking with pollster Andy Kohut and a couple of minutes.
But have the Democrats finished apportioning their delegates?
No, they're still, you know - well, a lot of the - if you look at a lot of the states - I mean, first of all, it's very interesting.
Hillary Clinton - it's really a draw what happened yesterday.
Obviously I would think that going into Super Tuesday perhaps a month ago, we would have thought that this would be Hillary Clinton country.

We see that a lot of states where you have an opportunity to see the candidates up close, Barack Obama does far better than the national reputation of Hillary Clinton which many thought may help her carry the day in Super Tuesday states.
But it was very, very close yesterday and, you know, Barack Obama may have won 13 states to compare to Hillary Clinton's eight states.
But at the same time, Hillary Clinton won the big ones.
She won California.
She won New York.
She won New Jersey.
And not close; it was pretty, you know, convincingly in not only on the delegate count, but in the popular vote she did very, very well.
So obviously, both candidates on the Democratic side can certainly claim victory.
And maybe for us political junkies, we are happy that the Democratic race goes on.
Some Democratic strategists may not be so happy because they would love a nice, tidy uniting of the Democratic Party, and then they'll face the general election as a united party.
On the Republican side by the delegate count on npr.com, I see John McCain…
Or in dot org.
…dot org, excuse me.
Okay.
Okay.
That John McCain is already more than halfway home.
He's pretty close to that, absolutely.
And it was a very good night for John McCain.
Not a great night.
And the reason I say that is that because all along we thought that Mike Huckabee and Mitt Romney would be fighting over social conservative votes and that would be to the benefit of John McCain.
And for the most part that was true.

We saw that in South Carolina, for example, a lot of people thought that Mitt Romney would've - I'm sorry, that Mike Huckabee would have won, but Fred Thompson and Mitt Romney and others took away conservative votes from him.
But Mike Huckabee did very well for himself yesterday especially winning the southern states - the Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee, as well as West Virginia and some other states.
And that was big for him.
A lot of us thought that Romney and Huckabee would split it enabling McCain to have a sweep of the south.
Huckabee obviously shows that he still has staying power.
He's very strong with evangelical voters as we saw in South Carolina and especially Iowa, which he won.
But so - the race is not over.
But clearly, if there is a Republican frontrunner, and there is, it is John McCain.
He didn't put away his rivals yesterday, although I would suspect that Mitt Romney would have liked to have had a much better night than he did.
But again, yes, John McCain is the frontrunner; no, the race is not over yet.
And again, we want to hear from listeners who voted yesterday or participated in caucuses or maybe worked the election.
What was it like at your balloting spot, at you caucus?
Our numbers for Republicans and independents: 800-344-3893.
For Democrats and independents: 800-344-3864.
And the e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
Ken?
You know, one thing that also occurred to me is that a lot of people in the states following Super Tuesday, they've been complaining for many weeks that they're not part of the excitement.
Their votes don't matter.
You know, Texas, Ohio, Maryland…
Pennsylvania.
…Virginia, Pennsylvania, exactly.
But now as it turned out, since it seems to be a fight for the Democratic - to the finish for the Democratic nomination, these votes do matter.
So the people who created this Super Tuesday thing were seemed to be haphazard and so, you know, unwieldy, yet it goes on.
And so those states that still - are still to come do matter.
And every - you know, back to the old thing: Every vote counts and every delegate counts.
Let's get a caller on the line.
This is Gladys(ph).
Gladys calling us from Phoenix, Arizona on the Republican line.
Hi.
I need to tell you what happened here in Phoenix yesterday.
I went over to vote to beat the five o'clock rush.
I went to my polling place and stayed in line for half an hour.
When I got inside the polling place, they said, we're out of provisional ballot envelopes.
And so I only have three more, so the rest of you will just have to wait.
I've sent for some more, but it may be a while.
Hmm.
Thanks, Michael.
And they couldn't give us a timeframe as to what a while was, but knowing how slow the process typically is, that could've been another hour.
I didn't stay to vote because I couldn't.
I had to be to an appointment in 45 minutes.
Well, we're going to count your vote right now, Gladys.
Who would you have voted for?
I would have for Mitt Romney, and he didn't win here in Arizona.
And I'm not the only person that left the polling place.
I have them announce to the people standing in line that there were no more provisional ballots, and that they have to wait.
They would leave the polling place open for those in line until seven o'clock.
But we may have been in line another hour and a half before we got those ballots.
And I'm sure you and some other people remain upset about that.
Very upset.
Because they didn't - I mean, why couldn't they have counted those envelopes earlier to know, gee, we're going to need these in another hour; we better call ahead and get these.
Well, we work in the news media and arithmetic is beyond us a lot of the time, too.
Thank you.
Thanks very much for the call, Gladys.
And let's go to the Democratic line.
And this is Joanne(ph).
Joanne with us from Wichita in Kansas.
Hi.
Hi.
In Wichita, Kansas last night we had freezing, blustery cold winds.
It's late.
It started to snow.
We were down at the courthouse.
Our state expected 15,000 statewide.
There were over 32 to 35,000 that turned out statewide.
We waited outside 40 to 50 minutes in a long line while they were trying to figure out what to do with everyone.
And then once they got everyone inside, they ran out of all the forms to register.

And I know for a fact from just what I heard from other people that worked in caucus scene, there were over a thousand that they had heard - you know, that they had counted so far that has left the Republican Party to come vote Democratic.
So it was in - the intensity around the country, Joanne, was amazing.
And I guess you're saying that was it was like in Wichita.
People are willing to wait in the freezing rain to vote.
It was an amazing sight for real democracy to see that many people laughing, talking, and freezing.
I mean, we were huddled together with another family.
So it was fantastic.
I'm just so happy today.
And I think Kansas really could be a blue state this year.
I hope so.
Thanks very much for the call, Joanne.
